choices.text: Abu Bakr
Panum
Enders
Robert Koch

questions.text: Earliest description of measles was given by
questions.solution:
• Abu Bakr Muhammad ibn Zakariya al-Razi (Rhazes), a Persian physician, provided one of the earliest detailed descriptions of measles.
  • He distinguished measles from smallpox and documented its characteristic symptoms in his medical works.
  • Rhazes' contributions during the 9th and 10th centuries significantly influenced medical knowledge in both the Islamic world and Europe.

Why Not Others

  • B. Panum: Known for studies on measles transmission in the 19th century but not the earliest description.
  • C. Enders: Awarded Nobel Prize for polio vaccine research, not related to measles' early description.
  • D. Robert Koch: Known for discoveries in bacteriology, notably tuberculosis, not measles.

Key Takeaway:

Rhazes provided one of the earliest recorded descriptions of measles, marking a significant contribution to medical knowledge in the medieval period.

choices.text: May occurs following measles vaccination
May lead to death within 48 hours
Causative organism in most cases is Staphylococcus aureus
Presenting symptoms are essentially of nervous system

questions.text: Which of the following statement about toxic shock syndrome is incorrect?
questions.solution:
The incorrect statement about toxic shock syndrome (TSS) is:

D. Presenting symptoms are essentially of nervous system.

  • Toxic Shock Syndrome (TSS) is a life-threatening condition primarily caused by the toxins from Staphylococcus aureus and, less commonly, Streptococcus pyogenes.
  • Systemic Symptoms: TSS presents with high fever, rash, hypotension, vomiting, diarrhea, and involvement of multiple organ systems like kidney, liver, and respiratory systems.
  • Nervous System Involvement: Neurological symptoms such as confusion or disorientation can occur but are secondary and due to overall systemic shock and hypoperfusion.
  • Incorrect Statement: D is incorrect because TSS is not centered on nervous system symptoms; it primarily affects various systems, with multi-organ symptoms as the hallmark.
  • Risk Factors: TSS can be associated with tampon use, post-surgical wounds, and certain infections but is rare following measles vaccination.

Why Not Others

  • A. May occur following measles vaccination: While very rare, TSS-like symptoms have been reported post-vaccination, potentially due to immune response or contamination.
  • B. May lead to death within 48 hours: TSS can progress rapidly to multi-organ failure and death if untreated, making prompt intervention crucial.
  • C. Causative organism in most cases is Staphylococcus aureus: Staphylococcus aureus exotoxins, especially TSST-1, are the primary cause of TSS in most cases.

Key Takeaway:

TSS is marked by multi-organ symptoms rather than nervous system focus, caused mainly by Staphylococcus aureus, and can escalate to fatal outcomes within 48 hours without immediate treatment.

choices.text: Seen commonly in school going children (6-15 years)
Equally common in boys and girls
Preventable through DPT vaccine best administered as subcutaneous mode
There are no carriers in this disease

questions.text: Which of the following statement about diphtheria is correct?
questions.solution:
• Gender Susceptibility: Diphtheria does not favour one gender over another, affecting both boys and girls equally in unvaccinated populations.
  • Age Range: While it historically affected school-age children(6-15 years), improved vaccination programs have shifted this; now, unvaccinated younger children and adults in low-vaccination regions are also at risk.
  • DPT Vaccine: Effective prevention of diphtheria is achieved through the DPT vaccine, which should be administered intramuscularly(not subcutaneously) for a stronger immune response.
  • Carrier State: Carriers can harbor Corynebacterium diphtheriae in the nasopharynx without showing symptoms, making asymptomatic spread a factor in disease persistence.

Why Not Others

  • A. Seen commonly in school-going children (6-15 years): Diphtheria is not exclusive to this age group and affects other age groups, particularly in unvaccinated areas.
  • C. Preventable through DPT vaccine best administered as subcutaneous mode: The DPT vaccine is given intramuscularly to produce optimal immunity, not subcutaneously.
  • D. There are no carriers in this disease: Corynebacterium diphtheriae can be carried asymptomatically, allowing spread by individuals without active symptoms.

Key Takeaway:

Diphtheria affects both boys and girls equally, with prevention through intramuscular DPT vaccine, and can persist through asymptomatic carriers, making vaccination vital to control its spread.

choices.text: Risk increases if the person is co infected with HIV
Risk is also high in persons with diabetes, other chronic disease
Incidence of disease is highest among adults
Higher proportion of cases are attributable to the reactivation of latent infection

questions.text: True about mycobacterium tuberculosis is EXCEPT
questions.solution:
• Incidence of disease is highest among adultsis not entirely correct. While adults have high incidence rates, children, elderly, and immunocompromised individuals are also at significant risk, especially in TB-endemic regions.
  • HIV Co-infection: HIV significantly elevates TB risk by compromising immunity, making it a major driver of TB incidence, particularly in high HIV-prevalence areas.
  • Chronic Disease Impact: Conditions like diabetes, chronic kidney disease, malnutrition, and substance use disorders increase TB susceptibility due to impaired immune responses.
  • Latent TB Reactivation: Many TB cases result from reactivation of latent TB, which occurs when dormant bacteria become active, especially in those with weakened immunity due to aging, chronic illness, or immunosuppressive therapy.
  • Global Burden & Vulnerable Populations: The burden of TB remains high globally, with vulnerable populations like healthcare workers, migrant populations, and prisoners also facing increased risk due to exposure and environmental factors.

Why Not Others

  • A. Risk increases if the person is co-infected with HIV: Correct, as HIV weakens immune defenses, making TB progression from latent to active more likely.
  • B. Risk is also high in persons with diabetes, other chronic diseases: True, chronic diseases impair immune function, raising susceptibility to TB.
  • D. Higher proportion of cases are attributable to the reactivation of latent infection:Correct; latent TB is a major contributor to TB cases, especially in older adults and those with immune suppression.

Key Takeaway:

TB risk factors include HIV co-infection, chronic diseases, and reactivation of latent TB, with incidence affecting not only adults but also children and vulnerable groups, underscoring the importance of TB control in high-risk populations.

choices.text: Smallpox is caused by the Variola virus
Smallpox can be prevented through vaccination
Smallpox has an animal reservoir which contributes to its spread
The World Health Organization (WHO) declared smallpox eradicated in 1980

questions.text: Which of the following statements about smallpox is NOT true?
questions.solution:
• Smallpox is caused by the Variola virus:
    • True. Smallpox is caused by the Variola virus, an orthopoxvirus that only infects humans.
    • Variola major and Variola minor are its two forms, with Variola major being the more severe, causing high mortality rates.
  • Smallpox can be prevented through vaccination:
    • True. The smallpox vaccine developed using the vaccinia virus was highly effective.
    • Vaccination efforts successfully prevented transmission and led to eradication, making it a milestone in infectious disease control.
  • Smallpox has an animal reservoir which contributes to its spread:
    • Not true. Smallpox had no animal reservoir; it was a human-only disease.
    • This absence of an animal reservoir was key in eliminating the virus entirely, as it could not survive outside human hosts.
  • The World Health Organization (WHO) declared smallpox eradicated in 1980:
    • True. After years of global vaccination campaigns, WHO declared smallpox eradicated in 1980.
    • This marked it as the first disease eradicated by human effort, an unprecedented achievement in global health.

Key Takeaways:

  • Smallpox, caused by the Variola virus, was eradicated by a global vaccination campaign.
  • Human-only disease with no animal reservoir, facilitating its successful eradication by 1980.

choices.text: Whooping cough is caused by the bacterium Bordetella pertussis
The characteristic symptom of whooping cough is a severe, hacking cough followed by a high-pitched "whoop" sound
Vaccination against whooping cough is included in the DTP vaccine series
Once infected, individuals develop lifelong immunity to whooping cough

questions.text: Which of the following statements about whooping cough (pertussis) is NOT true?
questions.solution:
• Whooping cough is caused by Bordetella pertussis:
    • Bordetella pertussisis the bacterium responsible for causing whooping cough. It infects the respiratory tract, leading to the characteristic coughing fits.
  • The characteristic symptom of whooping cough is a severe, hacking cough followed by a high-pitched "whoop" sound:
    • A severe, hacking cough is a hallmark symptom. After coughing, patients often make a high-pitched "whoop" sound as they try to inhale, particularly in young children.
  • Vaccination against whooping cough is included in the DTP vaccine series:
    • The DTP vaccine(Diphtheria, Tetanus, and Pertussis) provides protection against whooping cough and is given to infants and children in a series of doses.
  • Once infected, individuals develop lifelong immunity to whooping cough:
    • This is not true. Immunity to whooping cough wanes over time, and individuals who recover from the disease do not develop lifelong immunity. They may become susceptible to reinfection later.

Key Takeaways:

  • Whooping cough is caused by Bordetella pertussis and involves severe coughing with a "whoop" sound.
  • DTP vaccine offers protection, but immunity is not lifelong after infection.

choices.text: Chickenpox is caused by the virus Herpes simplex
The varicella-zoster virus can remain dormant in the body and reactivate later in life, causing shingles
Chickenpox primarily affects elderly individuals
Chickenpox can only be transmitted through direct contact with the skin lesions

questions.text: Which of the following statements about chickenpox (varicella) is correct?
questions.solution:
• Chickenpox is caused by the virus Herpes simplex:
    • Not correct. Chickenpox is caused by the varicella-zoster virus, a member of the herpesvirus family, not Herpes simplex (which causes cold sores and genital herpes).
  • The varicella-zoster virus can remain dormant in the body and reactivate later in life, causing shingles:
    • After an initial chickenpox infection, the varicella-zoster virus can remain dormant in nerve tissue. It can reactivate later in life, typically due to a weakened immune system, leading to shingles, characterized by painful skin rashes.
  • Chickenpox primarily affects elderly individuals:
    • Not correct. Chickenpox primarily affects children, though adults who have never been infected or vaccinated can also contract it. Elderly individuals are more prone to complications from chickenpox, but not the primary group affected.
  • Chickenpox can only be transmitted through direct contact with the skin lesions:
    • Not correct. While direct contact with skin lesions is a mode of transmission, chickenpox is also spread through airborne droplets when an infected person coughs or sneezes.

Key Takeaways:

  • Varicella-zoster virus causes chickenpox and can later reactivate as shingles.
  • Chickenpox is primarily a childhood disease but can have complications in adults and the elderly.

choices.text: Rubella is caused by the RNA virus
Rubella primarily affects elderly individuals
Rubella infection always results in severe symptoms and complications
Rubella can only be transmitted through direct contact with respiratory droplets

questions.text: Which of the following statements about rubella (German measles) is correct?
questions.solution:
• Rubella is caused by the RNA virus:
    • Rubella is caused by the rubella virus, a single-stranded RNA virus belonging to the togavirus family.
    • The virus is mainly transmitted through respiratory droplets from coughing or sneezing.
  • Rubella primarily affects elderly individuals:
    • Rubella primarily affects children and young adults, particularly those who have not been vaccinated.
    • While elderly individuals are not the primary group affected, pregnant women are at higher risk, especially for congenital rubella syndrome (CRS).
  • Rubella infection always results in severe symptoms and complications:
    • Rubella is usually a mild illness, especially in children, and may result in few or no symptoms.
    • The most serious complications occur when the virus is contracted during pregnancy, leading to miscarriage or birth defects.
  • Rubella can only be transmitted through direct contact with respiratory droplets:
    • Rubella is transmitted primarily through respiratory droplets, but it can also be passed from mother to fetus during pregnancy, causing congenital rubella syndrome.

Key Takeaways:

  • Rubella is caused by the rubella virus, an RNA virus.
  • It primarily affects children and young adults, with serious complications possible for pregnant women.
  • Transmission occurs through respiratory droplets and vertical transmission to the fetus.

choices.text: Influenza is caused by RNA viruses in the family Orthomyxoviridae
Influenza can be transmitted through respiratory droplets, direct contact, and contaminated surfaces
Influenza virus type A is the most likely to cause pandemics due to its ability to undergo antigenic shift
The influenza vaccine provides lifelong immunity against all strains of the virus

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the influenza virus is NOT true?
questions.solution:
• Influenza is caused by RNA viruses in the family Orthomyxoviridae:
    • Influenza is caused by viruses in the Orthomyxoviridae family, which are RNA viruses. There are three main types: A, B, and C. Types A and B are responsible for seasonal flu outbreaks, while type C causes milder illness.
  • Influenza can be transmitted through respiratory droplets, direct contact, and contaminated surfaces:
    • Influenza is highly contagious and spreads through respiratory droplets(from coughing or sneezing), direct contact, and contaminated surfaces. People can become infected by touching surfaces contaminated with the virus and then touching their mouth, nose, or eyes.
  • Influenza virus type A is the most likely to cause pandemics due to its ability to undergo antigenic shift:
    • Type Ainfluenza viruses are responsible for pandemics because they can undergo antigenic shift. This is a major genetic change in the virus, leading to new strains against which the population has little immunity, increasing the likelihood of widespread disease.
  • The influenza vaccine provides lifelong immunity against all strains of the virus:
    • The influenza vaccine does not provide lifelong immunity. Influenza viruses mutate rapidly, leading to new strains each flu season. This means the vaccine must be updated annually to protect against the most current strains of the virus. Immunity wanes over time, and the vaccine's protection is seasonal, not lifelong.

Key Takeaways:

  • The influenza virus is an RNA virus from the Orthomyxoviridae family.
  • Type Ainfluenza can cause pandemics due to antigenic shift.
  • The flu vaccine provides seasonal protection, not lifelong immunity, and must be updated annually.

choices.text: SARS is caused by the SARS-CoV virus
SARS was first identified in 2019 in Wuhan, China
SARS is primarily transmitted through respiratory droplets
There is no specific antiviral treatment for SARS

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) is NOT true?
questions.solution:
• SARS is caused by the SARS-CoV virus, a type of coronavirus identified in 2003 as the cause of a global outbreak of pneumonia-like illness.
  • The statement that SARS was first identified in 2019 in Wuhan, China is SARS was first identified in 2002-2003, and the outbreak in 2019 in Wuhan was caused by SARS-CoV-2, which causes COVID-19, a different disease.
  • SARS is primarily transmitted through respiratory droplets when an infected person coughs or sneezes. Close contact with infected individuals also facilitates transmission.
  • During the SARS outbreak, no specific antiviral treatment was available. Treatment was supportive, focusing on symptom relief and managing complications like respiratory failure.

Key Takeaways:

  • SARS was first identified in 2002-2003, not 2019.
  • It is caused by SARS-CoV, transmitted mainly through respiratory droplets.
  • No specific antiviral treatment was available during the outbreak.

choices.text: January 30, 2020
March 11, 2020
February 15, 2020
April 1, 2020

questions.text: The COVID-19 pandemic was declared a global pandemic by the World Health Organization (WHO) on:
questions.solution:
• The WHO declared COVID-19 a global pandemic on March 11, 2020. This announcement came after the SARS-CoV-2 virus, responsible for COVID-19, had spread globally, with cases reported in nearly every continent and country.
  • January 30, 2020, marked the declaration of a Public Health Emergency of International Concern (PHEIC), but not a pandemic. This was a step before the official global pandemic declaration.
  • By March 2020, the virus had rapidly spread, surpassing previous outbreaks in terms of cases, geographical spread, and severity, which led to the declaration of a pandemic.
  • February 15, 2020, is an incorrect date as the WHO had not yet declared the pandemic at that time.
  • April 1, 2020, is also incorrect, as the declaration had already been made in March.

Key Takeaways:

  • The WHO declared COVID-19 a global pandemic on March 11, 2020 as the virus spread rapidly across the globe.
  • A Public Health Emergency of International Concern was declared on January 30, 2020, prior to the pandemic.
  • The pandemic declaration marked a significant global health event with widespread cases and severe impacts.

choices.text: 5 days
7 days
10 days
18 days

questions.text: The extrinsic incubation period of vivax malaria is about
questions.solution:
• The extrinsic incubation period (EIP) refers to the time it takes for the Plasmodium vivax parasite to mature within the mosquito (typically an Anopheles species) after ingesting infected blood.
  • For vivax, the EIP typically ranges from 10 to 21 days, with 10 days being the most common duration under optimal conditions.
  • The ideal temperature for the EIP of P. vivax is around 25°C, where the development inside the mosquito occurs efficiently.
  • Lower temperatures(around 18°C or lower) can slow down the maturation process, extending the incubation period, while higher temperatures can shorten the EIP but may also reduce mosquito survival.
  • This period is crucial because it dictates when the mosquito becomes infectious to humans, able to transmit the parasite via subsequent bites.
  • The extrinsic incubation period is different from the intrinsic incubation period, which is the time it takes for the parasite to develop inside the human host..

Key Takeaways:

  • The extrinsic incubation period of vivax malaria is around 10 days under optimal conditions, though it can vary between 10 to 21 days.
  • This period depends on temperature, with 25°C being ideal for rapid development.
  • Understanding the EIP is crucial for vector control and preventing transmission to humans.

choices.text: Prevent recurrence in both infections
Prevent spread of infection in both infections
Prevent recurrence in vivax and spread of infection in falciparum
Prevent recurrence in falciparum and spread of infection in vivax

questions.text: Primaquine is given in chemotherapy of vivax and falciparum malaria basically to
questions.solution:
• Primaquine is an antimalarial drug used for two key purposes in the treatment of vivax and falciparum malaria:
    1. Prevent recurrence in vivax malaria:
      • vivax can form hypnozoites (dormant liver stages) that can reactivate months after the primary infection.
      • Primaquine targets and kills these hypnozoites in the liver, thus preventing the recurrence of malaria caused by vivax.
    2. Prevent spread of infection in falciparum malaria:
      • falciparum does not form hypnozoites but produces gametocytes, the sexual forms of the parasite responsible for transmission to mosquitoes.
      • Primaquine eliminates these gametocytes, preventing the spread of falciparum malaria to other people through mosquito bites.
  • Therefore, Primaquine is used to prevent relapse in vivax and to interrupt transmission of falciparum

Why Not Others:

  • Preventing recurrence in both infections is incorrect because Primaquine is effective for relapse prevention only in vivax malaria.
  • Preventing the spread of infection in both infections is incorrect because Primaquine prevents the spread in falciparum but relapse in vivax.
  • Preventing recurrence in falciparum and spread in vivax is incorrect because P. falciparum does not relapse and does not require relapse prevention, and P. vivax requires relapse prevention, not spread control.

Key Takeaways:

  • Primaquine prevents relapse in vivax malaria by targeting dormant liver stages (hypnozoites).
  • It prevents transmission of falciparum malaria by killing gametocytes, interrupting mosquito-to-human spread.
  • Primaquine is essential for comprehensive malaria treatment, addressing both recurrence and transmission.

choices.text: Thalassemia
Sickle cell anemia
Fetal hemoglobin
Duffy negative RBC

questions.text: Persons harboring which of the following trait are resistant to P vivax infection
questions.solution:
• Duffy negative RBCs confer resistance to vivax infection.
    • The Duffy antigen on red blood cells serves as a receptor for the vivax parasite to invade the cells.
    • Individuals who are Duffy negative(lack the Duffy antigen) cannot be infected by vivax, as the parasite cannot enter their red blood cells.
    • This trait is most common in populations of African descent, where it acts as a genetic protective factor against vivax malaria.
  • Other options:
    • Thalassemia and Sickle cell anemia provide protection against Plasmodium falciparum, not vivax. These conditions cause changes in red blood cell shape, making it harder for P. falciparum to invade.
    • Fetal hemoglobin does not provide specific resistance to vivax but may offer some protection against P. falciparum by reducing parasite growth in red blood cells.

Why Not Others:

  • A. Thalassemia and B. Sickle cell anemia offer protection against P. falciparum, not P. vivax.
  • C. Fetal hemoglobin may reduce the severity of P. falciparum infection but does not protect against P. vivax.

Key Takeaways:

  • Duffy negative RBCs provide resistance to vivax infection by preventing the parasite from entering red blood cells.
  • Thalassemia, sickle cell anemia, and fetal hemoglobin primarily provide protection against falciparum, not P. vivax.
  • The Duffy antigen is a key determinant in susceptibility to vivax malaria.

choices.text: Malaria
Hepatitis B
Hepatitis C
Hepatitis E

questions.text: As per FDCA requirements, blood collected for transfusion has to be tested against all the following EXCEPT
questions.solution:
• Blood collected for transfusion is routinely tested for various infectious diseases to ensure the safety of recipients. The required tests include:
    • Malaria: Donors are screened for malaria risk or history, but direct testing is uncommon.
    • Hepatitis B: Testing for Hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) and anti-HBc (antibodies to the core antigen) is mandatory.
    • Hepatitis C: Blood is tested for antibodies to Hepatitis C virus (HCV), and in some cases, HCV RNAis also tested.
    • HIV, Syphilis, and other infections are also part of the testing panel.
  • Hepatitis E, although it can be transmitted via blood transfusion, is not routinely tested in blood donations as it is less commonly transmitted through transfusion compared to Hepatitis B and Hepatitis C.

Why Not Others:

  • A. Malaria is part of the screening process for blood donations, especially for donors with a history or risk of malaria.
  • B. Hepatitis B is a required test under FDCA guidelines for blood safety.
  • C. Hepatitis C is also routinely tested, as it poses a significant risk for transmission through blood.

Key Takeaways:

  • Hepatitis E is not routinely tested in blood donations, as its risk of transmission through transfusion is lower.
  • Hepatitis B and Hepatitis C are mandatory tests in blood transfusion screening.
  • Ensuring safe blood transfusion involves testing for various infections, but Hepatitis E is not a routine requirement.

choices.text: Adult filariae dwell in human tissues and live for several years
Agents of lymphatic filariasis reside in lymphatic vessels and lymph nodes
Female worms produce microfilariae which circulate in the blood
Female worm lays up to 500 eggs which convert into larvae in 1 week

questions.text: True about life cycle of filariasis is Except
questions.solution:
• A. Adult filariae live in human tissues for several years: True. The adult worms reside in the lymphatic system, where they can live for 5-7 years, causing chronic filariasis.
  • B. Agents of lymphatic filariasis reside in lymphatic vessels and lymph nodes: True. Wuchereria bancrofti and Brugia malayi live in the lymphatic system, particularly in lymphatic vessels and nodes, leading to lymphatic damage.
  • C. Female worms produce microfilariae which circulate in the blood: True. Female worms release microfilariae (larvae), which circulate in the blood, where they can be picked up by mosquitoes during a blood meal.
  • D. Female worm lays up to 500 eggs which convert into larvae in 1 week: False. Female filarial worms do not lay eggs. They release microfilariae directly into the bloodstream, which develop into larvae inside mosquitoes, not in eggs. The larvae become infective after 1-2 weeks of development in the mosquito.

Key Takeaways:

  • Female filarial worms do not lay eggs; they release microfilariae into the blood, which are ingested by mosquitoes.
  • Microfilariae develop into infective larvae inside the mosquito over 1-2 weeks.
  • The life cycle of filariasis involves the interaction between the human host and the mosquito vector.

choices.text: Man is definitive host
Mosquito is Intermediate host
Human is the only important reservoir of infection of Filariasis
Takes 15-30 days for development of clinical symptoms since entry of infective larva

questions.text: Which of the following statement about the life cycle of filariasis is incorrect?
questions.solution:
• Man is the definitive host: Humans are where the adult worms live, mature, and reproduce, releasing microfilariae into the bloodstream.
  • Mosquito is the intermediate host: Mosquitoes (typically Culex, Anopheles, or Aedesspecies) ingest microfilariae from infected humans and then transmit the infective larvae during subsequent feeding.
  • Human is the only important reservoir: Humans serve as the primary and significant reservoir of filarial infection, as the disease does not have a significant animal reservoir.
  • Takes 15-30 days for clinical symptoms: This statement is incorrect because clinical symptoms of filariasis, such as lymphadenopathy or elephantiasis, typically develop months to years after infection, not within 15-30 days. The disease progresses slowly, with the adult worms causing long-term damage over time.

Key Takeaways:

  • Clinical symptoms of filariasis can take months to years to develop due to the slow progression of the disease.
  • Filariasis transmission involves a mosquito vector and human as both definitive host and main reservoir.
  • The clinical manifestation, such as elephantiasis, results from chronic inflammation and lymphatic damage, not from rapid onset post-infection.

choices.text: They occur within 15 days of entry of infective larva in to human host
During asymptomatic period, diagnosis is possible by eosinophilia, Lymphadenopathy and intradermal test
Occult filariasis is the result of hyper-responsive reaction of immune system
During the stage of Invasion, there is a micro-filariemia

questions.text: All the following are true about clinical manifestation of filariasis EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• Clinical manifestations of filariasis do not occur within 15 days. Symptoms usually develop months to years after infection, once larvae mature into adult worms.
  • During the asymptomatic period, diagnosis can be made by identifying eosinophilia, lymphadenopathy, and performing an intradermal test.
  • Occult filariasis involves an exaggerated immune response without detectable microfilariae in the blood.
  • During the invasion stage, there is microfilaremia, with microfilariae present in the blood, especially at night.

Key Takeaways:

  • Symptoms of filariasis typically develop months to years after the larvae enter the body.
  • In the asymptomatic period, eosinophilia and lymphadenopathy aid diagnosis.
  • Occult filariasis results from an immune response without visible microfilariae.

choices.text: Statement and reason both correct
Statement correct and reason incorrect
Statement and reason both incorrect
Statement incorrect and reasoning correct

questions.text: Brugian filariasis does not occur in India (statement) because its vector (Mansonia) is absent (reasoning) here
questions.solution:
• Statement: "Brugian filariasis does not occur in India" - This is incorrect. Brugian filariasis, caused by Brugia malayi, is found in several parts of India, including northeastern states(Assam, Bihar, Odisha) and Kerala. It is endemic in these regions and causes a range of clinical manifestations, such as elephantiasis and hydrocele.
  • Reasoning: "Its vector (Mansonia) is absent here" - This is also incorrect. The Mansonia mosquito is present in India, particularly in rural areas with marshy habitats. These mosquitoes play a critical role in the transmission of Brugia malayi, as they pick up microfilariae from infected humans and later transmit them through their bites.
  • Brugian filariasis is also found in neighboring Southeast Asia and China, where similar ecological conditions support the vector's survival.

Key Takeaways:

  • Brugian filariasis is present in India, particularly in endemic regions like the northeast and Kerala.
  • The Mansonia mosquito serves as the vector for Brugia malayi, and it is present in India, supporting transmission.
  • Clinical manifestations of Brugian filariasis include elephantiasis and hydrocele, typically developing months or years after infection.

choices.text: An arboviral disease
An emerging infectious disease
Occurs only as epidemic
In majority cases, it is a self limiting disease

questions.text: All the following are true about dengue fever EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• Dengue fever is caused by the dengue virus, which is an arboviral(arthropod-borne) disease transmitted primarily by the Aedes mosquitoes.
  • Dengue has become more widespread in the last few decades, especially in tropical and subtropical regions, and is considered an emerging infectious disease due to its increasing incidence.
  • Dengue fever can occur sporadically and is not limited to epidemics. While it often occurs in outbreaks, it can also be found endemic year-round in tropical regions where the vector mosquitoes are present.
  • Most cases of dengue fever are mild and self-limiting, resolving within a week. Severe forms, such as dengue hemorrhagic fever or dengue shock syndrome, are rare but more serious.

Key Takeaways:

  • Dengue fever is an arboviral disease spread by Aedes mosquitoes.
  • It is an emerging infectious disease and not limited to epidemics, as it can occur year-round in endemic areas.
  • Most cases are self-limiting and resolve within a week. Severe forms are less common but can be life-threatening.

choices.text: Major public health problem with presence of multiple serotypes of virus
Dengue hemorrhagic fever (DHF) an emerging problem with frequent cyclical outbreaks
Expansion of territory under the effect of dengue
Aedes albopictus is principal vector during the epidemics

questions.text: All the following statement about dengue in India are correct EXCEPT
questions.solution:
• Dengue is a major public health issue in India, with multiple serotypes (DEN-1, DEN-2, DEN-3, DEN-4) of the virus circulating, making it challenging to control.
  • Dengue hemorrhagic fever (DHF), a severe form of the disease, is an emerging problem in India, with frequent cyclical outbreaks, especially during the monsoon.
  • The territory affected by dengue has expanded over time, influenced by factors like urbanization and climate change.
  • The principal vector for dengue in India is Aedes aegypti, not Aedes albopictus, which is less efficient in transmission.

Key Takeaways:

  • Aedes aegypti is the primary vector for dengue in India.
  • Dengue remains a major public health problem, with multiple serotypes and increasing geographic spread.
  • The rise of dengue hemorrhagic fever (DHF) is a growing concern in cyclical outbreaks.

choices.text: Double stranded DNA virus
Flavi virus
Enveloped virus
Two subtypes of virus are Nakayama and Jagar 01

questions.text: True about JE virus is EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• Double stranded DNA virus: The Japanese Encephalitis (JE) virus is an RNA virus, not a DNA virus. It belongs to the Flaviviridae family, which is composed of RNA viruses.
  • Flavi virus: JE virus is a member of the Flavivirus genus within the Flaviviridae family.
  • Enveloped virus: JE virus is an enveloped virus, meaning it has a lipid membrane surrounding its RNA genome.
  • Two subtypes of virus are Nakayama and Jagar 01: JE virus has multiple strains, with Nakayama and Jagar 01 being the main subtypes.

Key Takeaways:

  • JE virus is an RNA virus from the Flavivirus genus.
  • It is an enveloped virus with subtypes like Nakayama and Jagar 01.

choices.text: Was identified in 1870's in Japan as summer encephalitis
In 1924 there were great epidemic in Japan
In 1938 virus was isolated from Culex tritaeniorhynchus
In 1940 virus was isolated from Aedes aegypti

questions.text: True about history of Japanese encephalitis EXCEPT
questions.solution:
• Was identified in 1870's in Japan as summer encephalitis: Japanese encephalitis was first identified in Japanin the 1870s, where it was initially called summer encephalitis due to its seasonal occurrence.
  • In 1924 there were great epidemic in Japan: A major epidemic of Japanese encephalitis occurred in Japan in 1924, marking a significant increase in cases.
  • In 1938 virus was isolated from Culex tritaeniorhynchus: In 1938, the virus responsible for Japanese encephalitis was isolated from Culex tritaeniorhynchus, which is a primary vector of the disease.
  • In 1940 virus was isolated from Aedes aegypti: Incorrect. The virus was not isolated from Aedes aegypti in 1940. Aedes mosquitoes are typically not the primary vectors for Japanese encephalitis; Culex species are responsible for its transmission.

Key Takeaways:

  • The virus causing Japanese encephalitis was isolated from Culex tritaeniorhynchus in 1938.
  • Aedes aegypti is not a primary vector for Japanese encephalitis.

choices.text: Certificate of vaccination against yellow fever is valid for 10 years
Validity begins from 10 days after the date of vaccination
Immunity is lifelong but revaccination advised at every 20 years
Vaccination certificate is asked only from those visitors who are coming from endemic area

questions.text: All the following are true about yellow fever vaccination EXCEPT
questions.solution:
• Certificate of vaccination against yellow fever is valid for 10 years: The yellow fever vaccination certificate is valid for 10 years from the date of vaccination, as per International Health Regulations (IHR).
  • Validity begins from 10 days after the date of vaccination: Protection begins 10 days after vaccination, and travellers are advised to wait 10 days before traveling to regions where yellow fever is a risk.
  • Immunity is lifelong but revaccination advised at every 20 years: Incorrect. Immunity from the yellow fever vaccine is considered lifelong, and there is no requirement for revaccination every 20 years. The general consensus is that a single dose provides lifelong immunity.
  • Vaccination certificate is asked only from those visitors who are coming from endemic area: True. Travelers from endemic areas are required to present a yellow fever vaccination certificate when traveling to countries with a yellow fever risk.

Key Takeaways:

  • Yellow fever vaccination provides lifelong immunity with no need for revaccination every 20 years.
  • Travel certificates are needed for visitors from endemic areas.

choices.text: Incubation period is 1-4 days
Man to man transmission
High fever, chills, cough, difficulty breathing, blood in sputum
Case fatality is 0-50%

questions.text: True about pneumonic plague is EXCEPT
questions.solution:
• Incubation period is 1-4 days: This is true. The incubation period for pneumonic plague typically ranges from 1 to 4 days after exposure to Yersinia pestis.
  • Man to man transmission: This is true. Pneumonic plague can be transmitted directly from person to person via respiratory droplets when an infected person coughs or sneezes.
  • High fever, chills, cough, difficulty breathing, blood in sputum: This is true. Symptoms of pneumonic plague include high fever, chills, cough, difficulty breathing, and blood in sputum.
  • Case fatality is 0-50%: This is incorrect. The case fatality rate for pneumonic plague can be as high as 100% if left untreated. With early diagnosis and antibiotic treatment, the fatality rate significantly decreases, but it remains much higher than 50% if untreated.

Key Takeaways:

  • Pneumonic plague has a high case fatality if untreated, potentially up to 100%.
  • Transmission occurs via respiratory droplets from person to person.

choices.text: Virus was first isolated from patients/mosquitoes in Tanzania (1953)
Zoonotic disease primarily occurs in chickens (poultry) and man are accidental host
It literally means 'that which bends up'
Arthropathies with pain, stiffness and swelling at multiple joints are characteristic symptom

questions.text: All the following statements about chikungunya virus are true EXCEPT
questions.solution:
• Virus was first isolated from patients/mosquitoes in Tanzania (1953): The chikungunya virus was first identified in Tanzania in 1953, from both mosquitoes and humans.
  • It literally means 'that which bends up': The word 'chikungunya' comes from a Makonde language word meaning 'that which bends up,' referring to the posture of patients who are often bent over due to joint pain.
  • Arthropathies with pain, stiffness and swelling at multiple joints are characteristic symptom: Joint pain, swelling, and stiffness are hallmark symptoms of chikungunya infection, with arthritis affecting multiple joints.
  • Cutaneous manifestations of chikungunya: An erythematous macular or maculopapular rash usually appears in the first 2-3 days of the illness and subsides within 7-10 days. It can be patchy or diffuse on the face, trunk and limbs. It is typically asymptomatic but may be pruritic [6-12].

Key Takeaways:

  • Chikungunya is mosquito-borne, not zoonotic, with humans as the primary host.
  • Symptoms include joint pain and swelling, often resulting in the bent posture characteristic of the disease.

choices.text: Disease of viral etiology
Transmitted by several species of hard ticks
Does occur to other species (extra human) as well
Seen exclusively in Japan and other Asia pacific countries

questions.text: Which of the statement about the kyasanur forest disease (KFD) is incorrect?
questions.solution:
• Kyasanur Forest Disease (KFD) is not exclusive to Japan and Asia-Pacific countries. It is primarily found in the Western Ghats of India.
  • KFD is viral in origin, caused by a flavivirus transmitted by several species of hard ticks. The disease is spread via ticks of the Ixodid
  • The disease affects various species of animals(extra-human species), including monkeys, which serve as reservoirs for the virus.
  • The disease is not confined to Japan and Asia-Pacific countries but is endemic in certain regions of India.

Key Takeaways:

choices.text: Direct contact with biological secretions of infected persons
Handling ill/ dead chimpanzees (infected)
Health care workers can be infected while attending patients
Bite of ticks and mites which have earlier bitten the infected person

questions.text: All are true about transmission of ebola virus EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• Direct contact with biological secretions of infected persons: Correct. Ebola is primarily transmitted through direct contact with bodily fluids (blood, saliva, vomit, feces, semen, sweat, etc.) from infected individuals.
  • Handling ill/dead chimpanzees (infected): Correct. Transmission can occur through handling infected animals, including chimpanzees, gorillas, and fruit bats, as they are natural reservoirs of the virus.
  • Health care workers can be infected while attending patients: Correct. Health care workers are at a high risk, particularly when infection control practices are not followed, due to close contact with infected patients' bodily fluids.
  • Bite of ticks and mites which have earlier bitten the infected person: Incorrect. Ebola is not transmitted through ticks or mites. Its primary mode of transmission is direct contact with infected bodily fluids.

Key Takeaways:


  • Fruit bats are believed to be the normal carrier in nature; they are able to spread the virus without being affected by it.[1] The symptoms of Ebola may resemble those of several other diseases, including malaria, cholera, typhoid fever, meningitis and other viral hemorrhagic fevers.[1] Diagnosis is confirmed by testing blood samples for the presence of viral RNA, viral antibodies or the virus itself.

choices.text: It is a nairovirus
It belongs to the genera Bunyaviridae
It belongs to flavivirus
It a used viral hemorrhagic fever

questions.text: All are true about causative agent of CCHF EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• It is a nairovirus:Correct. The causative agent of Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) is a Nairovirus, a genus within the Bunyaviridae family.
  • It belongs to the genera Bunyaviridae: Correct. CCHF virus is classified under the Bunyaviridae family and the Nairovirus genus, which includes other hemorrhagic fever viruses.
  • It belongs to flavivirus: Incorrect. CCHF is not caused by a Flavivirus. Flaviviruses include dengue, Zika, and yellow fever, which are distinct from CCHF, as they belong to different viral families.
  • It is a viral hemorrhagic fever: Correct. CCHF is a viral hemorrhagic fever, associated with high mortality, characterized by bleeding, fever, and multi-organ failure. It can cause a significant outbreak in humans, especially in tick-endemic areas..

Key Takeaways:


  • The CCHF virus is typically spread by tickbites or close contact with the blood, secretions, organs or other bodily fluids of infected persons or animals. Groups that are at high risk of infection are farmers and those who work in slaughterhouses. The virus can also spread between people via body fluids. Diagnosis can be made by detecting antibodies, the virus's RNA, or viral proteins (antigens). It is a type of viral hemorrhagic fever.

choices.text: Acute viral illness occurs in West Africa
First described in 1950
Disease was named after the town Nigeria
Disease was first originated in Japan

questions.text: True about Lassa fever is EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Lassa fever, also known as Lassa hemorrhagic fever, is a type of viral hemorrhagic fever caused by the Lassa virus.] Many of those infected by the virus do not develop symptoms. When symptoms occur they typically include fever, weakness, headaches, vomiting, and muscle pains. Less commonly there may be bleeding from the mouth or gastrointestinal tract. The risk of death once infected is about one percent and frequently occurs within two weeks of the onset of symptoms. Of those who survive, about a quarter have hearing loss, which improves within three months in about half of these cases.

The disease is usually initially spread to people via contact with the urine or feces of an infected multimammate mouse. Spread can then occur via direct contact between people. Diagnosis based on symptoms is difficult. Confirmation is by laboratory testing to detect the virus's RNA, antibodies for the virus, or the virus itself in cell culture. Other conditions that may present similarly include Ebola, malaria, typhoid fever, and yellow fever. The Lassa virus is a member of the Arenaviridae family of viruses.

  • Acute viral illness occurs in West Africa: Correct. Lassa fever is an acute viral illness primarily found in West Africa, particularly in countries like Sierra Leone, Liberia, Guinea, and parts of Nigeria.
  • First described in 1950: Correct. Lassa fever was first recognized in 1950, though the virus itself was identified later, in 1969.
  • Disease was named after the town in Nigeria: Correct. The disease was named after the town of Lassa in Nigeria, where it was first identified in 1969.
  • Disease was first originated in Japan: Incorrect. Lassa fever did not originate in Japan. It was first identified in Nigeria, and it is primarily endemic in West Africa.

Key Takeaways:

  • Lassa fever is endemic in West Africa, not Japan.
  • It was first identified in Nigeria, and the disease is named after the town of Lassa.
  • The disease was first described in 1950, but the virus was isolated later in 1969.

choices.text: Rat flea
Itch mite
Hard tick
Louse

questions.text: Epidemic typhus is transmitted by which of vector
questions.solution:
• Louse: Epidemic typhus is caused by Rickettsia prowazekii, transmitted by the body louse (Pediculus humanus corporis).
  • Rat flea: The rat flea is a vector for murine typhus/Endemic typhus, not epidemic typhus.
  • Itch mite: The itch mite causes scabies, unrelated to epidemic typhus.
  • Hard tick: Hard ticks are responsible for transmitting diseases like Rocky Mountain spotted fever, but not epidemic typhus.

Key takeaways:

choices.text: Various species of ticks act as vectors
Once infected, ticks remain infective for rest of their life
Ticks act as reservoir of infections
Infection is not transmitted to any mammals other than human beings

questions.text: All of the following statements about the transmission cycle in Indian tick typhus are correct EXCEPT
questions.solution:
Boutonneuse fever (also called Mediterranean spotted fever, fièvre boutonneuse, Kenya tick typhus, Indian tick typhus, Marseilles fever, or Astrakhan fever) is a fever as a result of a rickettsial infection caused by the bacterium Rickettsia conorii and transmitted by the dog tick Rhipicephalus sanguineus. Boutonneuse fever can be seen in many places around the world, although it is endemic in countries surrounding the Mediterranean Sea.

Presentation

After an incubation period around seven days, the disease manifests abruptly with chills, high fevers, muscular and articular pains, severe headache, and photophobia. The location of the bite forms a black, ulcerous crust (tache noire). Around the fourth day of the illness, a widespread rash appears, first macular and then maculopapular, and sometimes petechial.

Diagnosis

The diagnosis is made with serologic methods, either the classic Weil-Felix test, (agglutination of Proteus OX strains), ELISA, or immunofluorescence assays in the bioptic material of the primary lesion.

  • Various species of ticks act as vectors: True. Rhipicephalus species are the primary vectors of Indian tick typhus caused by Rickettsia conorii.
  • Once infected, ticks remain infective for rest of their life: True. Infected ticks remain infective for life and can pass the bacteria to new hosts.
  • Ticks act as reservoir of infections: True. Ticks not only transmit Rickettsia conorii but also act as reservoirs for the bacteria.
  • Infection is not transmitted to any mammals other than human beings: Incorrect. Rickettsia conorii can infect other mammals, particularly dogs, which act as reservoirs and play a role in the disease transmission cycle..

choices.text: Surface water reservoirs
Mud and soil
Food
Bite of carrier animal

questions.text: True about source of leptospirosis (contaminated) EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• Surface water reservoirs: True. Contaminated water, especially during floods, is a primary source of Leptospirosis. The bacteria can survive in water, and humans can get infected through direct contact.
  • Mud and soil: True. Soil and mud contaminated with the urine of infected animals, particularly rats, can be a source of Leptospirosis.
  • Food: True. Although rare, Leptospirosis can be transmitted through contaminated food, especially when food is exposed to infected animal urine.
  • Bite of carrier animal: Incorrect. Leptospirosis is primarily transmitted through direct contact with contaminated water, soil, or food, not by the bite of infected animals.

Key Takeaways:

choices.text: Mostly wild mammals (foxes, rabbits) in forests
Some domestic animals (cattle, swine)
Rodents living in sewers/fields
Vampire bats living in caves

questions.text: True about reservoir of leptospirosis EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• Mostly wild mammals (foxes, rabbits) in forests: True. Wild mammals like foxes and rabbits can serve as reservoirs for leptospirosis, especially in forested areas where they may come into contact with contaminated water or soil.
  • Some domestic animals (cattle, swine): True. Domestic animals such as cattle and swine can also harbor Leptospira bacteria, contributing to the spread of leptospirosis through their urine.
  • Rodents living in sewers/fields: True. Rodents, especially those living in sewers and fields, are major reservoirs for leptospirosis and play a critical role in the transmission of the disease.
  • Vampire bats living in caves: Incorrect. Vampire bats are not typically reservoirs for leptospirosis. While they can transmit diseases, Leptospira is not primarily associated with bats.

Key Takeaways:

  • The primary reservoirs of Leptospirosis include wild mammals, domestic animals, and rodents.
  • Vampire bats are not a significant reservoir for this disease.

choices.text: Organisms enter through mucosa and broken skin
Also through ingestion of food and absorbed through oral mucosa only
Man to man transmission is rare
Through contaminated milk and milk products

questions.text: True about modes of transmission of leptospirosis is EXCEPT
questions.solution:
• Organisms enter through mucosa and broken skin: True. Leptospirosis can be transmitted through mucous membranes (eyes, nose, mouth) or broken skin, especially when in contact with water, soil, or animal urine containing the Leptospira bacteria.
  • Also through ingestion of food and absorbed through oral mucosa only: True. Though rare, leptospirosis can be contracted through ingestion of contaminated food or water, where bacteria can be absorbed through the oral mucosa.
  • Man to man transmission is rare: True. Human-to-human transmission is exceptionally rare for leptospirosis, as the disease is usually spread through animal reservoirs, especially rodents.
  • Through contaminated milk and milk products: Incorrect. Leptospirosis is not transmitted through contaminated milk or milk products. Its primary mode of transmission is through direct contact with contaminated water, soil, or animal urine.

Key Takeaways:

  • Leptospirosis is mainly transmitted through contact with contaminated water, soil, or animal urine.
  • Transmission through milk and milk products is not a known or typical route for this disease.

choices.text: Contact with infected placenta
Ingestion of raw vegetables from infected farms
Person to person transmission
Inhalation of infected dust or aerosol

questions.text: Brucellosis can be transmitted by all of the following modes, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• Contact with infected placenta: True. Brucellosis is commonly transmitted through direct contact with infected animal tissues, including placenta, which can be a major source of infection for individuals handling livestock or aborted fetuses.
  • Ingestion of raw vegetables from infected farms: While not a common route, brucellosis can be contracted if vegetables are contaminated with bacteria from infected manure or soil. However, this is a less frequent mode of transmission.
  • Person to person transmission: Incorrect. Person-to-person transmission of brucellosis is extremely rare. While isolated cases have been reported through blood transfusions or sexual contact, the disease is predominantly zoonotic, transmitted mainly through animal products(e.g., milk, placenta) and direct animal contact.
  • Inhalation of infected dust or aerosol: True. Brucellosis can also be contracted through inhalationof infected aerosols or dust, particularly in environments like slaughterhouses, farms, or laboratories, where workers may be exposed to airborne particles containing the bacteria.

Key Takeaways:

  • Brucellosis is primarily transmitted through contact with infected animals or their products (like milk, placenta, and fetal tissues).
  • Person-to-person transmission is very rare and is not a common route of infection.
  • Inhalation of aerosolized bacteria is a known risk, particularly for workers in slaughterhouses or laboratories.

choices.text: Prepared by serial brain to brain passage of street viruses in rabbits
It has short fixed and reproducible incubation period of 4-6 days
It produces Negri bodies
It is used in preparation of vaccines

questions.text: Which of the following statement about fixed rabies virus is incorrect?
questions.solution:
• Prepared by serial brain to brain passage of street viruses in rabbits: True. The fixed rabies virus is typically prepared through serial passage of the street rabies virus (wild type) in rabbits, which attenuates the virus and makes it suitable for use in vaccines.
  • It has short fixed and reproducible incubation period of 4-6 days: True. The fixed rabies virus has a short, reproducible incubation period of 4-6 days, which is consistent and predictable, unlike the wild-type virus.
  • It produces Negri bodies: Incorrect. Negri bodies are characteristic of the wild-type rabies virus, and not of the attenuated, fixed virus used in rabies vaccines. The fixed virus is altered and does not produce these typical inclusion bodies.
  • It is used in preparation of vaccines: True. The fixed rabies virus is commonly used in the preparation of rabies vaccines due to its attenuated nature, which makes it safe for use in humans and it induces an immune response without causing disease.

KEY TAKEAWAYS:

choices.text: Single or multiple trans dermal bites or licks on broken skin
Nibbling of uncovered skin
Minor scratches
Licks on INTACT skin

questions.text: True about category III is:
questions.solution:
• Single or multiple transdermal bites or licks on broken skin: True. Category III represents the most severe exposure to rabies, which includes deep bites or licks on broken skin, allowing the virus to enter through a puncture wound. This requires immediate medical attention, including post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) with rabies immunoglobulin (RIG) and the rabies vaccination
  • Nibbling of uncovered skin: False. This refers to Category II exposure, which involves minor abrasions or scratches without significant bleeding. The risk is lower compared to Category III.
  • Minor scratches: False. This is also Category II exposure, which is considered a moderate risk for rabies transmission.
  • Licks on intact skin: False. This is considered Category I exposure, which poses a moderate risk, as the saliva of a rabid animal can contain the virus but may not always lead to infection.

Key Takeaways:

choices.text: Iceland
United Kingdom
Australia
Canada

questions.text: All the following countries do not have locally acquired infection cases of rabies EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• Canada: True. Rabies is still present in wildlife reservoirs(e.g., bats, raccoons, and foxes) in Canada. While human cases are rare, locally acquired rabies infections can still occur, especially from wildlife transmission.
  • Iceland: False. Iceland is rabies-free. The country has successfully eradicated rabies, and no locally acquired cases are reported.
  • United Kingdom: False. The UK is generally considered rabies-free, with no locally acquired cases in domestic animals. However, rare cases of rabies have been reported in bats but are not linked to local transmission among humans.
  • Australia: False. Australia is rabies-free with no locally acquired cases, although it does have a similar virus, Australian bat lyssavirus, found in bats, but not rabies.

Key Takeaways:

  • Canada still has locally acquired rabies infections, especially from wildlife sources like bats, raccoons, and foxes.
  • Iceland, the UK, and Australia are free from locally acquired rabies, though Australia has a different rabies-related virus.

choices.text: Inhalation of dust
Consumption of raw milk, flesh
Aerosol spray
Hard Tick

questions.text: Q fever is transmitted by the following EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• Inhalation of dust: True. Q fever is commonly transmitted by inhaling dust contaminated with Coxiella burnetii from infected animals, particularly in environments like farms, barns, or slaughterhouses.
  • Consumption of raw milk, flesh: True. Unpasteurized milk or raw animal products from infected animals can transmit the bacteria. Coxiella burnetii survives well in these products.
  • Aerosol spray: True. Q fever can be transmitted through aerosols, especially during activities like animal birthing, where the bacteria are released into the air.
  • Hard Tick: False. While Coxiella burnetii can be found in ticks, the tick-borne transmission to humans is extremely rare. It is not a significant route for the spread of Q fever.

Key Takeaways:

  • Q fever is primarily transmitted by inhalation of dust, consumption of raw milk, and aerosol spray, not by hard ticks.
  • Hard tick transmission is rare and not a major route for infection.

choices.text: Most common food borne infection
Can be transmitted even by intact egg
Incubation period is 6-12 days
Organism is resistant to extreme environmental conditions

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement about salmonellosis
questions.solution:
• Most common food borne infection: True. Salmonellosis is one of the most common foodborne infections, often caused by contaminated poultry, eggs, and dairy products.
  • Can be transmitted even by intact egg: True. Salmonella can contaminate intact eggs, as it can infect the ovaries of hens, contaminating the egg before the shell is formed.
  • Incubation period is 6-12 days: False. The incubation period for salmonellosis is typically 6-72 hours after ingesting contaminated food. The statement of 6-12 days is incorrect.
  • Organism is resistant to extreme environmental conditions: True. Salmonella is known to survive in a variety of extreme conditions, such as dry and acidic environments, making it resilient in different habitats.

Key Takeaways:

  • The incubation period for salmonellosis is 6-72 hours, not 6-12 days.
  • It is a common foodborne illness that can be transmitted through intact eggs, and is resistant to harsh environments.

choices.text: Zoonotic disease
Vector borne disease
Disease has been eradicated from the world
Transmission is very strongly related with seasonal variation

questions.text: All of the following statements about dracunculiasis are correct EXCEPT
questions.solution:
• Zoonotic disease: True. Dracunculiasis (Guinea worm disease) is a zoonoticinfection, meaning it can affect both humans and animals, particularly dogs, which are involved in the life cycle of the parasite.

  • Vector borne disease: True. The disease is transmitted via drinking water contaminated with copepods(water fleas) carrying Dracunculus medinensis
  • Disease has been eradicated from the world: False. The disease has not been eradicated. Though significant progress has been made, it is still found in a few African countries, and eradication efforts are ongoing.
  • Transmission is very strongly related with seasonal variation: True. Transmission peaks during the rainy season, when contaminated water sources become more common due to seasonal water changes.

Key Takeaways:

  • Dracunculiasis is a zoonotic, vector-borne disease strongly influenced by seasonal variations.
  • It has not yet been eradicated, though eradication efforts are close to succeeding.

choices.text: Salmonella food poisoning is the commonest
Staphylococcal food poisoning has shortest incubation period
Botulism is fairly common and also has a high fatality
Botulism is very rare but has a high fatality

questions.text: Which of the statement regarding various bacterial food poisonings is incorrect?
questions.solution:
• Salmonella food poisoning is the commonest: True. Salmonella is a leading cause of bacterial food poisoning, commonly found in poultry, eggs, and unpasteurized milk.
  • Staphylococcal food poisoning has the shortest incubation period: True. Staphylococcus aureus causes food poisoning with an incubation period of only 1-6 hours, the shortest among bacterial foodborne illnesses.
  • Botulism is fairly common and also has a high fatality: False. Botulism is rare, not fairly common, and has a high fatality rate if untreated. It is caused by Clostridium botulinum and its toxins, which can lead to respiratory failure.
  • Botulism is very rare but has a high fatality: True. Botulism is rare, but it carries a high fatality rate if not treated promptly due to the neurotoxin produced by the bacteria.

Key Takeaways:

  • Salmonella is the most common food poisoning.
  • Staphylococcal food poisoning has the shortest incubation
  • Botulism is rare, but highly fatal without prompt treatment.

choices.text: Human cases are the only reservoir
Cases range from asymptomatic to severe ones
Asymptomatic infections are common in children
Incubation period is longer in cases of Hepatitis A than hepatitis B

questions.text: True about reservoir of HAV is EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• Human cases are the only reservoir: True. Hepatitis A Virus (HAV) is exclusively transmitted through human-to-human contact, with no animal reservoir.
  • Cases range from asymptomatic to severe ones: True. HAV infections can present in various forms, from asymptomatic cases (especially in children) to severe cases, particularly in adults.
  • Asymptomatic infections are common in children: True. Children often remain asymptomatic when infected with HAV, while adults tend to show more severe symptoms.
  • Incubation period is longer in cases of Hepatitis A than Hepatitis B: False. Hepatitis A has a shorter incubation period(15-45 days, average 28 days) compared to Hepatitis B, which typically has an incubation period of 45-180 days.

Key Takeaways:

choices.text: Single stranded RNA virus
Properties are similar to flavivirus
Mainly transmitted by contaminated blood or blood products
Risk of sexual and maternal transmission is quite high

questions.text: True about HCV virus is EXCEPT
questions.solution:
• Single-stranded RNA virus: True. HCV is a single-stranded RNA virus, part of the Flaviviridae
  • Properties are similar to flavivirus: True. HCV is a member of the Flavivirus family, sharing structural and functional properties with other flaviviruses like dengue and yellow fever.
  • Mainly transmitted by contaminated blood or blood products: True. HCV is primarily transmitted through blood or blood products, particularly through sharing needles, blood transfusions, or organ transplants.
  • Risk of sexual and maternal transmission is quite high: False. While sexual and maternal transmission of HCV is possible, it is relatively rare compared to bloodborne transmission. The risk of sexual transmission is considered low, and maternal transmission primarily occurs during delivery in a minority of cases.

Key Takeaways:

  • HCV is a single-stranded RNA virus with similar properties to flavivirus.
  • Bloodborne transmission is the main route of infection.
  • The risk of sexual and maternal transmission is low, especially compared to blood exposure.

choices.text: Stable with extra reservoir survival
Sensitive to hypochlorite solution and autoclaving (30-60 minutes)
Less sensitive to radiation
Period of infectivity corresponds with clinical course of disease

questions.text: All the following statement about agent of hepatitis B are correct EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• Stable with extra reservoir survival: True. Hepatitis B virus (HBV) is highly stable outside the human body and can survive on surfaces or in dried blood for extended periods.
  • Sensitive to hypochlorite solution and autoclaving (30-60 minutes): True. HBV is sensitive to disinfectants like hypochlorite solution and can be effectively inactivated by autoclaving for a sufficient period (30-60 minutes).
  • Less sensitive to radiation: True. HBV is less sensitive to ionizing radiation compared to other viruses, which increases its resilience.
  • Period of infectivity corresponds with clinical course of disease: False. The period of infectivity for HBV does not necessarily align with the clinical course. Individuals can be asymptomatic carriers and still transmit the virus, especially in cases of chronic infection. Infection can occur even before symptoms appear.

Key Takeaways:

  • HBV is highly stable outside the body and can survive in environmental reservoirs.
  • HBV is sensitive to disinfectants and autoclaving but resistant to radiation.
  • The period of infectivity does not necessarily correlate with the clinical symptoms. Individuals can transmit HBV even without showing symptoms, especially during chronic infection.

choices.text: Man is the only reservoir
Most infections are subclinical
Virus can't be inactivated by pasteurization
Virus has good survival outside the reservoir

questions.text: True about Transmission of polio are all EXCEPT
questions.solution:
• Man is the only reservoir: True. Humans are the only natural reservoir for the poliovirus, meaning the virus only exists in human hosts.
  • Most infections are subclinical: True. Most poliovirus infections are asymptomatic or cause mild symptoms, with only a small percentage leading to severe disease such as paralysis.
  • Virus can't be inactivated by pasteurization: False. Poliovirus can be inactivated by pasteurization(heating to a specific temperature for a certain duration), which helps prevent the spread of poliovirus through food or drink.
  • Virus has good survival outside the reservoir: True. Poliovirus is highly stable in the environment and can survive for extended periods, especially in unsanitary water sources, contributing to its fecal-oral transmission.

Key Takeaways:

  • Poliovirus is transmitted primarily via the fecal-oral route due to its ability to survive in the environment.
  • Pasteurization can inactivate poliovirus, ensuring food safety.
  • Most infections are asymptomatic, but in rare cases, poliovirus can cause severe disease like paralysis.

choices.text: Virus is found in oropharyngeal secretion and faeces of infected person
No animal source has been demonstrated
Cases are most infectious 7 to 10 days before and after the onset of symptoms
Fomites play important role in spread of disease

questions.text: True about Transmission of polio are EXCEPT
questions.solution:
• Virus is found in oropharyngeal secretion and faeces of infected person: True. Poliovirus is present in saliva and faeces during the acute phase of infection, especially when the virus is actively replicating.
  • No animal source has been demonstrated: True. Poliovirus is human-specific, and there are no animal reservoirs for the virus.
  • Cases are most infectious 7 to 10 days before and after the onset of symptoms: True. Poliovirus is most contagious during the few days before and after the onset of symptoms, especially through respiratory droplets and fecal matter.
  • Fomites play important role in spread of disease: False. Fomites (inanimate objects or surfaces) are not a major transmission route for polio. The primary mode of transmission is fecal-oral, often via contaminated water, food, or direct contact with infected individuals.

Key Takeaways:

  • Poliovirus is primarily spread through fecal-oral transmission.
  • It is most infectious before and after symptoms
  • Fomites are not a significant transmission route for polio.

choices.text: It is gram-positive anerobic, organism
Its spores give drum stick appearance
Produce an exotoxin responsible for causation of disease
It cannot survive in external environment

questions.text: All the following statements are true about tetanus causing organism except:
questions.solution:
• It is a gram-positive anaerobic organism: True. Clostridium tetani is a gram-positive bacterium and is anaerobic, meaning it thrives in environments lacking oxygen.
  • Its spores give drumstick appearance: True. The spores of tetani have a drumstick-like shape, a hallmark feature seen under a microscope.
  • It produces an exotoxin responsible for causation of disease: True. tetani produces tetanospasmin, a potent exotoxin responsible for muscle spasms and the hallmark symptoms of tetanus.
  • It cannot survive in external environment: False. Clostridium tetani can survive in the external environment in the form of resilient spores. These spores are resistant to heat, drying, and other environmental stressors, allowing them to persist in soil, dust, and other environments for long periods.

Key Takeaways:

  • Clostridium tetani is a gram-positive, anaerobic bacterium with resilient spores that can survive in the external environment.
  • The drumstick appearance of its spores and the production of tetanospasmin toxin are key features of the disease.

choices.text: Caused by chlamydia trachomatis but other pathogens often contribute
Blinding trachoma is characterized by entropion, trichiasis and corneal ulcer
Nonblinding trachoma never becomes blinding trachoma
Blinding trachoma requires urgent action

questions.text: Which is incorrect about trachoma?
questions.solution:
• Caused by Chlamydia trachomatis but other pathogens often contribute: Correct. Chlamydia trachomatisis the primary causative agent, but other environmental bacteria can exacerbate the infection.
  • Blinding trachoma is characterized by entropion, trichiasis, and corneal ulcer: Correct. Blinding trachoma leads to severe scarring, entropion(inward eyelid turning), trichiasis (inward-growing eyelashes), and corneal ulcers, which can result in blindness.
  • Nonblinding trachoma never becomes blinding trachoma: Incorrect. Nonblinding trachoma can progress to blinding trachoma if untreated. Early-stage trachoma may not cause blindness, but repeated infections and scarring can cause severe complications over time.
  • Blinding trachoma requires urgent action: Correct. Immediate intervention is essential to prevent permanent blindness. Treatment typically involves antibiotics, surgery for eyelid deformities, and improving hygiene to prevent further infections..

Key Takeaways:

  • Trachoma is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis, and its progression can lead to severe complications like blindness.
  • Nonblinding forms can progress to blinding trachoma if untreated, making early intervention critical.
